awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: Enabling Precise and Automated Insecurity Analysis of Middleware on Mobile Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
During the past decade, middleware on mobile platforms (such as the Application Framework in Android and the Core Services layer in iOS) has been flourishing, but the insecurity analysis of such middleware has been lagging behind. For example, while comprehensive studies have been conducted at the application layer of the Android system, there is very limited work analyzing the Android Application Framework (Android Framework, for short), a middleware layer in the Android system. The two billion Android mobile devices and the many Android Things devices all rely on the system services provided by Android Framework. Recently, many vulnerabilities of Android Framework are exposed, showing that Android Framework is vulnerable and exploitable. Given the critical role of Android Framework, a vulnerability in the framework can be exploited to launch large-scale cyber attacks and cause serious harms to user security and privacy. However, the insecurity analysis of Android Framework has been rather ad hoc, imprecise, and requires much manual effort, mainly because there is a severe lack of techniques and tools developed for insecurity analysis of such middleware on mobile platforms (MoMP). This research project seeks to fill the gap by developing new techniques and tools for insecurity analysis of MoMP like Android Framework and consequently lead to more secure and trustworthy computing environments for the huge number of smartphone and Internet-of-Things (IoT) device users. Educational resources developed in this project, including course modules on mobile computing security and vulnerability discovery, will be disseminated through a dedicated web site. Collaborations with the industry will be sought to transfer the technology to interested software companies and government entities that perform insecurity analysis of MoMP.

The project will develop new architectural designs, algorithms and techniques for precise and automated insecurity analysis of MoMP. To make the research concrete, demonstrations will be created for the Android Framework for mobile smartphones, tablets and IoT devices, and the first platform for precise and automated insecurity analysis of Android Framework will be built, combining current software analysis techniques, such as symbolic execution, hybrid dynamic/static analysis, and cross-process and cross-layer software analysis, to make them capable of analyzing complex and large-sized MoMP like Android Framework. The platform will be evaluated and applied to discovering various types of zero-day vulnerabilities and generating proof-of-concept exploits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the past decades, middleware on mobile platforms (such as the Application Framework in Android and the Core Services layer in iOS) has been flourishing, but the insecurity analysis of such middleware has been lagging behind. For example, while the application layer of Android has been extensively studied, there is very limited work on analyzing Android Application Framework (Android Framework, for short), a middleware layer on the Android system. Android Framework is an integral and foundational part of the Android system. Each of the two billion Android mobile devices and each Android Things IoT device rely on the system services of Android Framework to run. However, the insecurity analysis of Android Framework has been rather ad hoc, imprecise, and requires much manual effort, as there is a severe lack of techniques and tools developed for insecurity analysis of middleware on mobile platforms (MoMP).

 

This project filled the gap by proposing architectural designs, algorithms and techniques for precise and automated insecurity analysis of MoMP. Due to the unique characteristics of MoMP, many new challenges are raised and require dedicated research efforts. To make the research concrete, we have demonstrated the proposed ideas and techniques on Android Framework for mobile phones, tablets and IoT devices, and built the first platform for the insecurity analysis of Android Framework. This research has been critical proactive effort towards discovering security defects in Android Framework. In addition, it has been a significant exploring step along the important but under-explored direction—insecurity analysis of middleware on mobile platforms, and enhanced the layer of foundational software for mobile computing and IoT.

 

Intellectual Merit: The project has led to the first platform for precise and automated insecurity analysis of Android Framework. Our research has provided the capabilities of analyzing Android Framework through a series of innovative results: (1) Architecture that supports precise analysis. An architecture for scalable insecurity analysis of Android Framework has been proposed. (2) Development of the enabling techniques. New ideas, algorithms and techniques that enable the insecurity analysis have been proposed, and a set of tools that can be used by analysts will be developed. (3) Insecurity Analysis of Android Framework. The proposed platform has been evaluated and applied to discovering various types of zero-day vulnerabilities and generating proof-of-concept exploits. The project has provided new and significantly deeper understanding on how to conduct insecurity analysis of MoMP.

 

Broader Impacts: This research has significant broader impacts in research, industry, home- land security, and education. (1) This project has led to substantial progress in insecurity analysis of Android Framework and thus more secure and trustworthy computing environments for the huge number of Android phone and IoT device users. (2) We have open sourced the platform, such that it can be used by Android device vendors and government agencies to analyze Android Frameworks (e.g., their custom versions of Android Frameworks). A publicly accessibly GitHub repository has been created including the source code and documents of the project: https://github.com/Android-Framework-Symbolic-Executor/Centaur (3) Educational resources from this project, including course modules on Android security and vulnerability discovery, have been developed. (4) The research results have been published in CCS, Oakland, USENIX Security, NDSS, MobiCom, and MobiSys. The project has inspired much follow-up research.
